@graph.name: Language Data Ontology
description: This is an experimental language data ontology based on OLAC terms for use in the ATAP and LDaCA projects

@graph.name: Annotation
rdfs:comment: The resource includes information which annotates, describes or otherwise an some other linguistic record.
rdfs:label: Annotation

@graph.name: Coded
description: The resource contains a coded analysis or annotation

@graph.name: CollectionEvent
rdfs:comment: A description of an event at which one or more PrimaryTexts were captured,  eg as video or audio
rdfs:label: CollectionEvent

@graph.name: CollectionProtocol
rdfs:comment: Description of how this Object or Collection was obtained – such as strategy used for selecting written source texts, or the prompts given to participants
rdfs:label: CollectionProtocol

@graph.name: DerivedResource
rdfs:comment: A resource is derived from another resource, via some automated process, eg a downsampled video or an abstract of a resource which  is not an annoation (description)
rdfs:label: DerivedResource

@graph.name: Dialogue
description: An interactive discourse with two or more participants. Examples of dialogues include conversations, interviews, correspondence, consultations, greetings and leave-takings.

@graph.name: Drama
description: A planned, creative, rendition of discourse with two or more participants intended for presentation to an audience.

@graph.name: ElicitationTask
description: The collection protocol includes a task-based prompt to participants

@graph.name: Formulaic
description: The resource is a ritually or conventionally structured discourse.

@graph.name: Gesture
description: The resource contains non-linguistic gestural communication (ie not sign language)

@graph.name: Handwritten
description: The resource was written using a writing implement such as pen, pencil, brush or computer stylus  (From Nyingarn - TODO check this)

@graph.name: Informational
description: Discourse whose primary purpose is to inform the reader about the natural or social world.

@graph.name: Interview
description: The resource is conversation where one or more speakers are directing the conversation

@graph.name: Lexicon
description: The resource includes a systematic listing of lexical items.

@graph.name: Ludic
description: Ludic discourse is language whose primary function is to be part of play, or a style of speech that involves a creative manipulation of the structures of the language. Examples of ludic discourse are play languages, jokes, secret languages, and speech disguises.

@graph.name: Oratory
description: The art of public speaking, or of speaking eloquently according to rules or conventions. Examples of oratory include sermons, lectures, political speeches, and invocations.

@graph.name: OrganizationBasedLicense
rdfs:comment: A licence document  setting out rights and oblications could be based copyright or other rights  based on membership of an Organization. The organization could be any  group of people with appropriate governance from self selected individuals who agree to license terms, to groups of researchers, to ad-hoc groups of members of a community
rdfs:label: OrganizationBasedLicense

@graph.name: OrganizationDepositLicense
rdfs:comment: A license document setting out terms for deposit into a repository by one or more identified groups
rdfs:label: OrganizationDepositLicense

@graph.name: OrganizationReuseLicense
rdfs:label: OrganizationReuseLicense
rdfs:comment: A license document setting out terms for reuse of data by one or more identified groups

@graph.name: Orthographic
description: The resource contains annotations using  orthography (a writing ssytem) as opposed to a coded analysis such as a phonetic transcription

@graph.name: PartOfSpeech
description: TODO - Olac definitons are circular

@graph.name: PersonSnapshot
rdfs:comment: This class represents a snapshot of a Person in time, in their role as a contributor to one or more creative works. The purpose of this class  is to caputre the metadata that applies to a person at a particular time, as their name, age, gender, social status  etc may be different over time.
rdfs:label: PersonSnapshot

@graph.name: Phonemic
description: TODO - Olac definitons are circular

@graph.name: Phonetic
description: TODO - Olac definitons are circular

@graph.name: Phonological
description: TODO - Olac definitons are circular

@graph.name: PrimaryText
rdfs:comment: This is a primary resource: the object of study, such as a literary work, film, or recording of natural discourse
rdfs:label: PrimaryText

@graph.name: Procedural
description: An explanation or description of a method, process, or situation having ordered steps.

@graph.name: Prosodic
description: TODO - Olac definitons are circular

@graph.name: Report
description: A factual account of some event or circumstance.

@graph.name: Semantic
description: The resource contains annotations of the meaning of another resource

@graph.name: Session
description: A collection event which is a recording or elicitation Session with particpants

@graph.name: SignLanguage
description: This resource contains  sign language

@graph.name: Song
description: "Words or sounds [articulated] in succession with musical inflections or modulations of the voice" OED.

@graph.name: SpokenLanguage
description: This resource contains  spoken language

@graph.name: Syntactic
description: The resource contains annotation or analysis describing  the syntactic structure of another resource

@graph.name: TextSelectionCriteria
description: A description of the criteria used to select texts in a collection

@graph.name: Thesaurus
description: The resource contains  a list or data structure consisting  of words or concepts arranged according to sense.

@graph.name: TimeAligned
description: The resource contains a written or coded annotation(s) which has data aligning the annotation(s)  with a PrimaryText

@graph.name: Narrative
description: A monologic discourse which represents temporally organized events. Types of narratives include historical, traditional, and personal narratives, myths, folktales, fables, and humorous stories.

@graph.name: Transcription
description: The resource contains a transcription, which  is a written (orthographic) or coded  representation of an audio or visual signal.

@graph.name: Translation
description: The resource has been translated from one natual language to another

@graph.name: Typeset
description: The resource has been formatted for display

@graph.name: Typewritten
description: The resource contains text produced on a tpyewriter (From Nyingarn - TODO check this)

@graph.name: WrittenLanguage
description: The resource contains written material using a standard or conventional orthography with conventions for punctuation, capitalization etc

@graph.name: annotationOf
rdfs:comment: This resource contains some kind a description such as a translation, transcription or other analysis of the resource it references
rdfs:label: annotationOf

@graph.name: annotator
rdfs:comment: The participant produced an annotation of this or a related resource.
rdfs:label: annotator

@graph.name: author
rdfs:comment: The participant contributed original writings to the resource.
rdfs:label: author

@graph.name: channels
rdfs:comment: Number of audio channels this resource contains (eg 1, 2 5.1)
rdfs:label: channels

@graph.name: collectionEventType
rdfs:comment: An event with a start and end time during which data are gathered from partipants, or from other materials
rdfs:label: collectionEventType

@graph.name: collectionProtocolType
rdfs:comment: A description of the process used to collect or collate data, such as prompts given to participants, or how texts are selected for inclusion in a collection
rdfs:label: collectionProtocolType

@graph.name: compiler
description: This refers to someone who creates a single resource with multiple parts, such as a book of short stories, or a person who produces a corpus of resources, which may be archived separately.
example: A compiler of a book of short stories or a CD with several songs on it; a collector of a corpus of recordings in some language or on a given topic; a person who assembles a suite of software tools.
rdfs:comment: The participant is responsible for collecting the sub-parts of the resource together.
rdfs:label: compiler

@graph.name: consultant
description: This term is commonly used by field linguists for the native speakers who work with them in describing and analyzing a language. They contribute their expertise in their native language to the resource, although their speech, sign, or writing may not appear directly in the resource. In some parts of the world the preferred term for this role is "informant".
rdfs:comment: The participant contributes expertise to the creation of a work.
rdfs:label: consultant

@graph.name: dataInputter
rdfs:comment: The participant was responsible for entering, re-typing, and/or structuring the data contained in the resource.
rdfs:label: dataInputter

@graph.name: depositor
rdfs:comment: The participant was responsible for depositing the resource in an archive.
rdfs:label: depositor

@graph.name: derivationOf
rdfs:comment: This resource references another resource that is derived from it such as a downsampled audio or video file, or text extracted from a PDF
rdfs:label: derivationOf

@graph.name: developer
description: A software programmer, designer, or analyst; a designer of a questionnaire or research task.
rdfs:comment: The participant developed the methodology or tools that constitute the resource, or that were used to create the resource.
rdfs:label: developer

@graph.name: doi
rdfs:comment: A digital Object Identifier
rdfs:label: doi

@graph.name: editor
description: This role includes anyone whose role was editorial in nature, such as proof-readers, debuggers, testers, etc. It may overlap the Compiler role in some cases.
rdfs:comment: The participant reviewed, corrected, and/or tested the resource.
rdfs:label: editor

@graph.name: geoJSON
rdfs:comment: A valid GEOJson feature or feature collection as a string that can be parsed as JSON
rdfs:label: geoJSON

@graph.name: hasAnnotation
rdfs:comment: This resource references another resource that describes it  such as a translation, transcription or other analysis
rdfs:label: hasCollectionProtocol

@graph.name: hasAnnotation
rdfs:comment: This resource  was assembled or collected according to the linked protocol
rdfs:label: hasAnnotation

@graph.name: hasDerivation
rdfs:comment: This resource references another resource that is derived from it such as a downsampled audio or video file, or text extracted from a PDF
rdfs:label: hasDerivation

@graph.name: illustrator
rdfs:comment: The participant contributed drawings or other illustrations to the resource.
rdfs:label: illustrator

@graph.name: indexableText
rdfs:comment: Indicates one or more  target File that  together contain the full text of an item  – each  file should indicate its language
rdfs:label: indexableText

@graph.name: interpreter
description: The choice between 'interpreter' and 'translator' may depend on the dynamics of the resource creation event or process. Generally, if the participant is translating 'live'; that is, while the speaker or signer is speaking or signing, she or he should be identified as an interpreter. Also, some discourse genres include a participant who interprets or explains a performance of some kind.
example: A person translating from English to ASL during a speech; a Kuna chief who interprets a chant that another chief has just performed, thus completing the ceremony.
rdfs:comment: The participant translates in real-time or explains the discourse recorded in the resource.
rdfs:label: interpreter

@graph.name: interviewee
rdfs:comment: The participant was a respondent in an interview
rdfs:label: interviewee

@graph.name: interviewer
rdfs:comment: The participant conducted an interview that forms part of the resource.
rdfs:label: interviewer

@graph.name: deidentified
rdfs:comment: This data in this item has had identifying information removed, or in the case of a person the name is an alias
rdfs:label: isDeIdentified

@graph.name: licensedOrganization
rdfs:comment: Indicates a group of people who have the rights described in this license
rdfs:label: licensedOrganization

@graph.name: participant
description: This role is intended for minor participants such as audience members or other peripherally-involved participants in the event. These interlocutors need not have been physically present. They could be participants in some form of long-distance communication, such as lurkers in an online discussion, or they may have participated in general sense of having allowed the creation event to take place, such as the mayor of an indigenous community.
rdfs:comment: The participant was present during the creation of the resource, but did not contribute substantially to its content.
rdfs:label: participant

@graph.name: performer
description: It is recommended that this term be used only for creative participants whose role is not better indicated by a more specific term, such as 'speaker', 'signer', or 'singer'.
example: A person performing a ceremony or delivering an oration or a sermon; native speakers re-enacting a traditional genre of speech, such as ritual greetings or insults; an actor or musician.
rdfs:comment: The participant performed some portion of a recorded, filmed, or transcribed resource.
rdfs:label: performer

@graph.name: person
rdfs:comment: This property references a Person item which represents the persistent identity of one or more ContributingPerson items.
rdfs:label: person

@graph.name: photographer
rdfs:comment: The participant took the photograph, or shot the film, that appears in or constitutes the resource.
rdfs:label: photographer

@graph.name: recorder
rdfs:comment: The participant operated the recording machinery used to create the resource.
rdfs:label: recorder

@graph.name: register
description: Specifies the type of register (any of the varieties of a language that a speaker uses in a particular social context [Merriam-Webster]) of the contents of a language resource
rdfs:comment: Specifies the type of register (any of the varieties of a language that a speaker uses in a particular social context [Merriam-Webster]) of the contents of a language resource
rdfs:label: register

@graph.name: researchParticipant
rdfs:comment: The participant acted as a research subject or responded to a questionnaire, the results of which study form the basis of the resource.
rdfs:label: researchParticipant

@graph.name: researcher
rdfs:comment: The resource was created as part of the participant's research, or the research presents interim or final results from the participant's research.
rdfs:label: researcher

@graph.name: responder
description: This person's voice can be heard (or their words can be read) in the resource, typically saying the language-appropriate equivalent of "uh-huh", "amen", "you don't say", etc. This role is sometimes referred to as a "yes-sayer", "backchanneler, or "co-conversant".
rdfs:comment: The participant was an interlocutor in some sort of discourse event.
rdfs:label: responder

@graph.name: signer
description: Signers are those whose gestures predominate in a recorded or filmed resource. (This resource may be a transcription of that recording.)
example: Participants in a recorded conversation, elicitation session, or informal narration would be termed Signers. Audience members who do not participate beyond the occasional backchannel would be termed Responders.
rdfs:comment: The participant was a principal signer in a resource that consists of a recording, a film, or a transcription of a recorded resource.
rdfs:label: signer

@graph.name: singer
rdfs:comment: The participant sang, either individually or as part of a group, in a resource that consists of a recording, a film, or a transcription of a recorded resource.
rdfs:label: singer

@graph.name: speaker
description: Speakers are those whose voices predominate in a recorded or filmed resource. (This resource may be a transcription of that recording.)
example: Participants in a recorded conversation, elicitation session, or informal narration would be termed Speakers. Audience members who do not participate beyond the occasional backchannel would be termed Responders.
rdfs:comment: The participant was a principal speaker in a resource that consists of a recording, a film, or a transcription of a recorded resource.
rdfs:label: speaker

@graph.name: sponsor
rdfs:comment: The participant contributed financial support to the creation of the resource.
rdfs:label: sponsor

@graph.name: transcriber
rdfs:comment: The participant produced a transcription of this or a related resource.
rdfs:label: transcriber

@graph.name: translator
rdfs:comment: The participant produced a translation of this or a related resource.
rdfs:label: translator
